title: Stephen Colbert Gets a Standing Ovation at the Emmys, Crowd Chants ‘Stephen’
summary: Stephen Colbert received a standing ovation at the Emmys. Here's what happened when he made an appearance and what he said about his show's cancellation.
story: Stephen Colbert received an overwhelmingly supportive welcome from the crowd as he appeared on stage at the 2025 Emmys to present the first award of the night.

“The Late Show With Stephen Colbert,” who announced this summer that his show will be ending in May 2026, was greeted with a standing ovation before he announced the nominees for outstanding lead actor in a comedy series on Sunday, Sept. 14.

His peers stood up and began to chant “Stephen!” as soon as they spotted him. Colbert laughed and took a moment to take in the admiration. “Thank you very much! You’re very kind! Sit down. We’ve got to go!” he told the audience.
Colbert encouraged the crowd to return to their seats before joking that he was in need of a job.
“While I have your attention, is anyone hiring?” he quipped. He then said that his resume hadn’t been updated in a while before unfolding a paper to reveal a throwback black-and-white headshot.
Colbert added that there was only one entry on his resume and ventured into the crowd to hand the document to Harrison Ford. He playfully asked if the actor could pass it on to Steven Spielberg.
Toward the end of the show, the crowd chanted his name again as he accepted the Emmy for outstanding talk series for “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert.”

“I want to thank CBS for giving us the privilege to be part of the ‘Late Night’ tradition, which I hope continues long after we’re no longer doing this show,” he said in his speech. He also expressed gratitude for the people on stage with him, the 200 professionals he works with, his fans for 20 years, his wife and his kids.
He said that while working on the show he had intended for it to be about love but it later became a series about loss.

“Ten years later in September of 2025, my friends I have never loved my country more desperately. God bless America. Stay strong. Be brave. And if the elevator tries to bring you down, go crazy and punch a higher floor!” he concluded.
As mentioned, Colbert revealed during the July 17 episode of his show that “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” is “going away” next year and will not be replaced.

“Before we start the show, I want to let you know something that I found out just last night. Next year will be our last season. The network will be ending the ‘Late Show’ in May,” he said as the crowd reacted by booing. “And, yeah, I share your feelings. It’s not just the end of our show, but it’s the end of ‘The Late Show’ on CBS.”
He explained, “I’m not being replaced, this is all just going away.”
Colbert inherited “The Late Show” from David Letterman when he stepped away in 2015.
“The Late Show” also won a Creative Artists Emmy Award on Sept. 7 in the category of outstanding directing for a variety series.
While accepting the Emmy for outstanding writing for a variety series on Sunday, “Last Week Tonight With John Oliver” senior writer Daniel O’Brien appeared to reference Colbert’s cancellation.
“We are honored to share (this category) with all writers of late-night political comedy while that is still a type of show that’s allowed to exist,” he said.

title: Why Britt Lower Wrote 'Let Me Out' On the Back of Her Emmys Acceptance Speech
summary: "Severance" star Britt Lower's Emmys acceptance speech is a reference to her character.
story: Britt Lower can now add her name to the illustrious list of Emmy winners for outstanding lead actress in a drama series.
The 40-year-old took home her first trophy for her portrayal of Helly R. in the dystopian series "Severance."

During her acceptance speech, the Emmy winner thanked the cast and crew of the AppleTV+ series, which includes Adam Scott, John Turturro, Zach Cherry, Patricia Arquette and fellow winner Tramell Tillman, calling them "heroic." She also thanked executive producer, Ben Stiller and show creator Dan Erickson.
Viewers watching the 77th Annual Emmys spotted a cryptic message written on the back of her acceptance speech. Penned in all capital letters were the words "LET ME OUT."

Fans of "Severance" will likely understand the note, given that Lower's character, Helly R., has spent much of her time desperately trying to escape her job at Lumon, going to extreme lengths to free her "innie."

The dark drama, which just completed its second season, tracks a group of office workers who've agreed to have their memories surgically divided between their work selves, or "innies" and their personal life, or "outies."
Lower's Emmy note, is a tongue-in-cheek nod to her character's desperate quest for freedom. At one point, her character writes "let me out" on her arms.

After premiering in 2022, "Severance" scored two Emmys and was nominated for an impressive 27 more this year including nominations for outstanding directing for a drama series, outstanding supporting actress for Arquette and supporting actor nods for Turturro and Cherry, among others.

Other nominees for outstanding lead actress in a drama series at this year's Emmys were Kathy Bates ("Matlock"), Sharon Horgan ("Bad Sisters"), Keri Russell ("The Diplomat") and Bella Ramsey ("The Last of Us").
During her acceptance speech, Lower paid tribute to her fellow nominees saying, “It’s a privilege to even be mentioned alongside such an incredible group of artists. Wow."
After seeing Lower's "LET ME OUT" note, "Severance" fans took to social media to express how tickled they were at the clever reference, posting "britt you’re a genius" and calling her an "icon."
In an interview after her Emmy win, Lower said she was excited to celebrate with her new dog, who is named Bowtie.

title: 'Adolescence' Star Erin Doherty Wins an Emmy. What it Means to Her: EXCLUSIVE
summary: What Erin Doherty's first Emmy award for Adolescence means to her.
story: For her work in "Adolescence," Erin Doherty took home the award for best supporting actress in an anthology series or movie at the 2025 Emmys.
Ahead of the awards show, Doherty told TODAY.com what the Emmy win — her first — might mean.

“I couldn’t even tell you. It sounds quite cliche, but I love the whole team aspect of what it is to make something and be a creative person. I've always found awards so kind of disarming in that sense — because I’m like, Oh, God, can’t it just be wonderful for everyone?" she said.
She said she hoped she could "be present" the night of the Emmys and "have a gorgeous time celebrating with everyone who made it."
Doherty dedicated the speech to her older sister and gave a shoutout to her girlfriend Sinead Donnelly.

In "Adolescence," Doherty plays a child psychologist tasked with speaking to a 13-year-old boy accused of murdering his classmate. She and her co-star Owen Cooper filmed their tense conversation in one take.

Minutes before, her co-star Owen Cooper also won an Emmy, making him the youngest male actor to win — ever. Cooper told TODAY.com of his nomination, “It just shows how well the show is done," and said a win would be a "good way to end."
Follow along on our Emmys live blog.
In an interview with TODAY.com, Doherty said people often come up to her wanting to get deep about the show's theme of social media's effect on young people.

"They just want to have a conversation about it. They say, 'I loved you in that,' and then, 'What do you think about it?' It's so bizarre to me that I get to engage with that conversation with people who've seen it," she said.
"Adolescence" creators Jack Thorne and Stephen Graham also took home the Emmy for best writing for a limited or anthology series.

title: Owen Cooper Shares the Significance of Winning His 1st Emmy: EXCLUSIVE
summary: Owen Cooper won an Emmy for “Adolescence.” He told TODAY.com what the moment meant to him in an interview.
story: Owen Cooper captivated viewers with his stunning portrayal of Jamie Miller, a 13-year-old boy accused of killing one of his classmates, in Netflix’s “Adolescence.”

Cooper’s heart-wrenching performance in the critically-acclaimed British crime drama earned the now 15-year-old actor his first Emmy nomination, making him the youngest Emmy nominee for outstanding supporting actor in a limited series or movie.
Moments ago, Cooper picked up the coveted award, which now cements him as the youngest male actor to win an Emmy — ever.
The honor was previously held by a then 16-year-old Scott Jacoby, who had won best supporting actor in 1973 for his role in the made-for-TV drama film “That Certain Summer.”
Meanwhile, the youngest female Emmy winner is Roxana Zal, who won in 1984 for best supporting actress in a limited series or movie at 14 for “Something About Amelia.”
Prior to his historic win on Sunday night, Cooper spoke exclusively to TODAY.com about the significance of his then potential win and what he felt about being honored.
“I know there’s a lot of pressure on me, but it’s just, obviously, it’s a bonus,” he says. “And it just shows how well the show is done. So, yeah, it’s just a good way to end.”
During his acceptance speech, Cooper elaborated on his win and how it fit into the trajectory of his life.

"A couple years back I didn't expect to be in the United States, let alone here. Tonight proves if you listen, you focus and you step out of your comfort zone, you can achieve anything in life. I was nothing three years ago. I'm here now," he said.
"If you step out of your comfort zone, who cares if you get embarrassed? Anything can be possible," he continued.
He went on to thank his parents, the show's creators, Netflix and more. "It may be my name on the wall but it really belongs to the people behind the camera," he said.

Cooper’s poignant thoughts about his role in the film during his acceptance speech are just a snapshot of the impact that the award-winning series has had on him and the many people the show affected.
Co-created by and co-starring Stephen Graham, who played Jamie’s dad Eddie Miller, “Adolescence” is inspired by real events, which included a series of recent local stabbings.

“There was an incident where a young boy (allegedly) stabbed a girl,” Graham told Tudum. “It shocked me. I was thinking, ‘What’s going on? What’s happening in society where a boy stabs a girl to death? What’s the inciting incident here?’ And then it happened again, and it happened again, and it happened again. I really just wanted to shine a light on it, and ask, ‘Why is this happening today? What’s going on? How have we come to this?’”

In his interview with the outlet, Graham said that he hoped the show would help answer the question, “What is happening to our young men these days and what are the pressures they face from their peers, from the internet and from social media?”

Aside from the ripped-from-the-headline effect, the series has also struck a chord with critics and parents alike. Following its release on March 13, “Adolescence” became the No. 1. English-language show on Netflix in the U.S. It also garnered a critics approval rating of 100% on Rotten Tomatoes, which has since been updated to 98% with 109 critic reviews.
In a Sunday Focus segment on TODAY March 30, NBC’s Daniele Hamamdjian explored the impact of the series and the national conversation it sparked about online culture and the complex issues of teens.

Speaking to psychologists about some of those hot button issues, Hamamdjian told Sunday TODAY’s Willie Geist that experts advise that the best way to start a conversation with kids about such issues is to “get off your own device.”

“Adults need to model the right behavior, monitoring screen time and the types of content viewed,” she said. “The point .. is to remind kids that there are real relationships out there and in the real world. Not just online and in apps and parents should encourage in person interactions.”

title: How Nate Bargatze's Emmys Opening Was Inspired by His Viral 'SNL' Sketch
summary: Comedian Nate Bargatze opened the 77th Annual Emmy Awards with a throwback to his famous Saturday Night Live George Washington sketch.
story: Nate Bargatze wasted no time getting the laughs in the opening moments of the 77th Annual Emmy Awards.

Instead of kicking things off with a traditional monologue, the "Hello World" comedian opened the show with a throwback to one of his most popular sketches from his time hosting Saturday Night Live: "Washington's Dream."
Except instead of portraying America's first president, however, Bargatze instead took on Philo T. Farnsworth, otherwise known as the man who first invented television.
In the skit, Bargatze described a future in which, among other things, people would watch TV while "sitting on the toilet."

He also poked fun at streaming ("a new way for companies to lose money"), Stanley Tucci's two Italy-set travel shows, some of this year's Emmy-nominated shows and specific networks, among other TV-related topics.
Bargatze was joined by SNL cast members Mikey Day, Bowen Yang and James Austin Johnson.
Follow along for live Emmys updates.
Fans will likely remember Bargatze's 2023 portrayal of George Washington during SNL's 49th season in which America's first president shares his dreams for the future while at an army camp.

In his "speech" to the troops, which include Day, Yang and Kenan Thompson, Bargatze decreed that the U.S. would forsake the easy-to-figure-out metric system for a weights and measures system complicated beyond compare, among other declarations.
The memorable sketch has since racked up more than 25 million views on YouTube and become a fan favorite.
Bargatze reprised the role of Washington for a SNL sequel in October 2024 for part two of "Washington's Dream."

In last year's sketch, the comedian could be found leading soldiers across the Delaware River in 1776 and deciding to do "our own thing" with the English language including spelling words "different ways."
“And we will create our own foods and name them what we want, like the hamburger,” Bargatze declared, to which Day responded, “Made of ham, sir?”
“If it only were that simple," pondered Bargatze in the memorable skit.

After opening the Emmys with the SNL throwback sketch, Stephen Colbert did a short monologue, followed by an opening monologue by Bargatze, in which the comedian announced he was donating $100,000 to the Boys & Girls Club of America depending how long Emmy speeches go.

title: Tramell Tillman Makes Emmys History, Dedicates Win to His Mom: 'This Is For You'
summary: Tramell Tillman had an historic night at the 2025 Emmys, becoming the first Black actor to win outstanding actor in a supporting role.
story: Tramell Tillman had an historic night at the 2025 Emmys.
After being announced as the winner of the outstanding supporting actor in a drama series award, the 40-year-old “Severance” star became the first-ever Black man to win in the category.
As he accepted his award, Tillman dedicated his significant achievement to his first acting coach, who also happens to be his mother.

“You remember what you want to remember. You make time for what you want to make time for. Do the work. Show up. And most importantly, for the love of God, don’t embarrass me in public,” he began. “My first acting coach was tough, y’all. But all great mothers are.”
Follow along for live updates.
The camera then panned to show his mom proudly in the audience touching her heart.
He turned to face her and continued, “Mama, you were there for me when no one else was and no one else would show up. Your loving kindness stays with me. And this is for you.”
Tillman thanked the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences before concluding, “I am full. I am humbled. And as my mama would say, ‘Oh, look at God!”
The actor won for his portrayal of Seth Milchick in the Apple TV+ thriller series, which leads the pack with 27 nominations tonight.

title: How Much Money Was Donated to the Boys & Girls Club at the 2025 Emmys?
summary: Comedian Nate Bargatze has a scheme for keeping Emmys speeches short. Here's the
story: Comedian Nate Bargatze came up with an ingenious way to ensure speeches at the 2025 Emmys will be quick.
Prior to the awards show on Sunday, Sept. 14, Bargatze, who is serving as host for the first time, shared his plan to keep the ceremony on schedule during an appearance on “Jimmy Kimmel Live.”
“What I came up with is I’m going to donate $100,000 to the Boys & Girls Club. That’s what the show’s starting out with,” he said.
He further explained his plan when the 2025 Emmys began and Bargatze’s idea came into fruition.

“I know how hard you guys have all worked to get here. I’m not trying to take anything away. Forty-five seconds, that’s what you got,” he said. “If you want to do more than that, do it on social media later, more people are going to see it there anyway.”

As he revealed his $100,000 donation, the figure appeared on a screen next to him. The audience applauded before he continued, “Remember how fun that was because this part is hard to say. If you stay at 45 seconds, it stays at $100,000.”
The nominees gasped as they realized what would happen if they went past the 45-second limit.

“Every second you go over 45 seconds, we will deduct $1,000 away from the Boys & Girls Club. That’s tough. It’s brutal. What are you gonna do, though? You know, I can’t change it. This is a game I made up, and these are the rules,” he joked.
Bargatze cheerfully added that if the winners go under, he will put $1,000 for every second back into the donation fund.
He revealed that Seth Rogen, who won the first award of the night for outstanding lead actor in a comedy series, unknowingly added $5,000 thanks to his brief remarks.
To finish his monologue, Bargatze quipped, “Don’t go crazy, though, because, like, I’m paying for this. Some of you go over a little, some go under. Do the right thing.”
The number later went down to $98,000 after Katherine LaNasa delivered her remarks for best supporting actress for "The Pitt."

He later announced that fellow comedian JB Smoove was helping keep track of the time. JB Smoove, a Boys & Girls Club alum, was shown sitting in the audience with two members of Boys & Girls Club also in attendance.

More children appeared throughout the night, as well as a ticker monitoring how much money remained in the fund. Toward the end of the evening, the amount dipped into into the red as speeches became longer.
Bargatze appeared on stage at the end of the show and said the number was "embarrassing."

But, thankfully, Bargatze, who stood beside Smoove and four children from the Boys & Girls Club on stage as the ceremony wrapped, said, "CBS is going to add $100,000. I will give $250,000. It takes us to $350,000 for the Boys & Girls Club. Thank you guys so much for being out here!"

title: Jeremy Allen White Skipped the Emmys This Year. Here's Why
summary: Why isn't Jeremy Allen White at the 2025 Emmys? Here's why he skipped the ceremony to attend this friend's wedding
story: Jeremy Allen White is up for his third Emmy award, but actor will be missing the 2025 awards ceremony this year.
The 34-year-old is attending his best friend's wedding and won't be joining his fellow castmates at the 77th Emmy Awards, TODAY.com can confirm.
"The Bear" stars attending include Ebon Moss-Bachrach, Liza Colón-Zayas, Molly Gordon and Matty Matheson.

"The Bear" star won best actor in a comedy series at the Emmys back to back in 2023 and 2024 for his portrayal of Carmen "Carmy" Berzatto, a fine-dining chef who returns to Chicago to take over the family restaurant, The Bear, after the unexpected death of his older brother.
This year marks his third nomination in the category. If he wins again, the actor won't be at the Peacock Theater in Los Angeles to pick up his trophy, per an X post by Variety.

After winning the outstanding actor in a comedy series Emmy in 2024, White thanked his family and said of "The Bear" cast saying, "My beautiful cast: I love you forever, I love to work with you. I want us to be in each other’s lives forever," and that the show "changed my life."

White isn't the only cast member up for an Emmy this year. Edebiri is up for outstanding lead actress, Moss-Bachrach is nominated for outstanding supporting actor, Colón-Zayas is nominated for outstanding supporting actress. Guest stars Olivia Colman and Jamie Lee Curtis are also up for Emmys, among others.
White is competing against Adam Brody ("Nobody Wants This), Seth Rogen ("The Studio"), Jason Segel ("Shrinking") and Martin Short ("Only Murders in the Building") for the trophy this year.
The drama-comedy has won 21 Primetime Emmys since first debuting in 2022 and is nominated for 13 more at this year’s awards’ ceremony including Outstanding Comedy Series.
Along with starring in "The Bear," White is portraying the Boss himself, Bruce Springsteen, in the upcoming movie "Springsteen: Deliver Me From Nowhere," which will be released on Oct. 24.
Based on the book “Deliver Me From Nowhere,” the film will chronicle the lead up to Springsteen’s 1982 ‘Nebraska’ album, the record that made the singer-songwriter a superstar.

title: What Time Are the Emmys? How to Watch 2025 Awards Show
summary: What time are the 2025 Emmy Awards? When do they start? What channel are they on? How do you watch and stream the Emmys?
story: The 2025 Emmy Awards are nearly underway, bringing together Hollywood's brightest stars to celebrate the best of television.
The 77th annual awards show airs live Sunday, Sept. 14, with comedian Nate Bargatze hosting from Los Angeles’ Peacock Theater.
Follow live Emmys 2025 coverage

The 2025 Emmys will honor shows that aired new episodes from June 2024 to May 2025, including the latest seasons of “Severance,” “The Last of Us,” “The Bear,” “Abbott Elementary” and “The White Lotus.”
Here's how to tune in to the awards show set to honor the best of the best in television.
When Are the Emmy Awards?
The 77th annual Emmy Awards will take place Sunday, Sept. 14.
What Time Are the Emmy Awards?
The Emmy Awards will take place Sunday night at 8 p.m. ET. Red carpet coverage will kick off at 7 p.m. ET.
The show is scheduled to run until 11 p.m. ET.
How to Watch the Emmy Awards
The Emmy Awards will air live Sunday, Sept. 14, on CBS. The show will also stream live on Paramount+ for premium plan subscribers.
Who’s Nominated at the Emmy Awards?
Going into Sunday night's show, Apple TV+'s "Severance" leads the pack with a whooping 27 nominations. "The Penguin" received 24, while "The Studio" and "The White Lotus" received 23 nods.
Click here for a list of nominees.
Who's Presenting at the Emmy Awards?
The official lineup of presenters at the Emmy Awards feature stars from "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit," "Gilmore Girls" and more.

Some of the names include Alexis Bledel, Elizabeth Banks, Jason Bateman, Jennifer Coolidge, Walton Goggins, Mariska Hargitay, Jude Law, Jenna Ortega, Sarah Paulson, Sydney Sweeney and Catherine Zeta-Jones, among others.
Who Has Won Emmy Awards?
The winners began before the primetime ceremony started. Bryan Cranston won for "The Studio," Juliane Nicholson won for "Hacks" and Merritt Wever won for "Severance."
Follow the entire winners list here.

title: Who Is Dressed as a Labubu at the Emmys? Mystery Revealed
summary: Who is dressed as a Labubu at the 2025 Emmys?
story: The stars have begun making their way down the red carpet at the 2025 Emmys, and one has already captured the internet’s attention.
While some opted to dress to the nines in gowns and tuxedos, a reality television starlet chose to arrive at the award show on Sunday, Sept. 14 dressed as a life-size Labubu.
So, who was the famous face with the eye-catching ensemble?
Follow live Emmys 2025 coverage
“RuPaul’s Drag Race” Season 17 star Joella was revealed to be the celebrity behind the mask.

Joella completed her look by pairing it with a Chinese takeout box as a purse. She teased her appearance at the 2025 Emmys on Instagram as the red carpet began by sharing a close-up on her Instagram story of her look and intricate makeup.
In another post, Joella credited Lauren Rose for the outfit and Angel Monroe as her makeup artist.

Joella wasn’t the only Season 17 alum who decided to think outside the box for the 2025 Emmys. Fellow “RuPaul’s Drag Race” star Kori King channeled the King of Pop Michael Jackson for television’s biggest night.
Kori King sported one of Jackson’s classic looks: red shirt, black fedora and black pants.
Fans complimented the drag queens’ style and sense of humor on X.
One wrote, “The slaysian diva of los angeles, aka joella stuns at the 2025 emmys.”
Another deemed Kori King “THE FUNNIEST PERSON ALIVE.”
“I was born in the right generation i love seeing Kori king as Micheal Jackson and Joella as a labubu for the literal emmys,”  a third said.
One X user dreamed of Joella and Kori King meeting Beyoncé, who is nominated for her Netflix NFL halftime show, “Beyonce Bowl.”
“Obsessed with there being a real possibility of Beyoncé running into Kori King as Michael Jackson and Joella as a labubu,” the tweet read.

title: Who's Hosting the 2025 Emmys? What to Know About Nate Bargatze
summary: Nate Bargatze hosts the 2025 Emmy Awards on September 14. What to know about the record-breaking comedian's approach to TV's biggest night on CBS.
story: For Nate Bargatze, the Tennessee-born comic who’s become one of America’s most beloved stand-up performers, hosting the 77th Emmy Awards represents the culmination of a career built on understated charm and everyman relatability.
Known for his commitment to clean humor, Bargatze had a series of successful comedy specials, like “The Greatest Average American” and “The Tennessee Kid.”
After decades in the business, he shot to fame after his 2023 “Saturday Night Live” appearance. His 2024 tour crowned him the highest-grossing comedian of the year.
Follow live Emmys 2025 coverage
Now, Bargatze is approaching his hosting duties with a clear mission: keep things light, fun and genuinely enjoyable for everyone in attendance.
“I don’t want to be mean,” Bargatze told USA Today when discussing his hosting philosophy. “I don’t want to make someone sad that’s there.”
In an interview with TheWrap, he echoed the sentiment, saying that he wants to avoid making people in the audience feel uncomfortable.

“When the celebrities are there, you want to be able to see them afterwards and it not be weird. Jokes are naturally going to be kind of mean. That’s the only way it’s going to be funny,” he said. “We’re going to have jokes about shows, but I’m not trying to be, I don’t want to make anybody sad.”

And to CNN, he said something similar: “I would not want to do something that’s just inherently mean, and to really be mean to a person. That would break my heart if I found out anybody was really hurt by anything.”

What viewers can expect, however, is stripped-down compared to traditional Emmy spectacle. Don’t look for elaborate song-and-dance numbers or musical interludes under Bargatze’s watch. “I would be terrible at that stuff,” he said to USA Today. “And I don’t want the show to be bad. I want it to be good. So I don’t plan on singing. I hope I don’t.”

He's also devised an unconventional strategy for keeping speeches under 45 seconds each. Bargatze promised a personal $100,000 donation to the Boys & Girls Club of America — and the number will change depending on how speeches go.
He explained the scheme on "The Jimmy Kimmel Show."

“Everybody gets 45 seconds to do all the thank-yous,” Bargatze said. “So what I came up with is I’m going to donate $100,000 to the Boys & Girls Club. … That’s what the show’s starting at. When everybody uses their 45 seconds, if someone goes over, we take away $1,000 a second every time they go over.”
This year’s ceremony follows the 2024 show helmed by father-son duo Dan and Eugene Levy.

The 2025 nominees represent a particularly strong field, with Apple TV+’s workplace thriller “Severance” leading the pack with a 27 nominations. Close behind is HBO’s “The Penguin,” Colin Farrell’s transformative turn as the Batman villain earning the limited series 24 nominations, while Apple TV+’s behind-the-scenes comedy “The Studio” nabbed 23 nods.
Viewers can also expect to see on-stage appearances from a diverse roster of celebrity presenters, including Tina Fey, Parker Posey, Jenna Ortega, and Mariska Hargitay.
The 77th Emmy Awards air live on Sunday, Sept. 14.
Follow live Emmys 2025 coverage here.

title: Travis Kelce Reveals How He Felt Proposing to Taylor Swift: ‘A Few Tears’
summary: Travis Kelce is sharing rare details about his proposal to Taylor Swift
story: Travis Kelce is sharing rare details about his proposal to Taylor Swift.

The pop star and Kansas City Chiefs tight end shared news of the proposal on Aug. 26 in the engagement announcement heard 'round the world. The post featured photos of Kelce on bended knee while Swift held his face, seemingly in a garden.
"The palms were definitely sweating," Kelce said of the proposal in an interview with Fox Sports' Erin Andrews. "I'm an emotional guy, so there were a few tears here and there.
"It's been an exciting ride up until this day, and I can't wait to spend the rest of my life with her," he added.

Describing life with his newly minted fiancée, he said Swift "has brought excitement and a joy for life that made me a better man, made me a better person and made me just that much more comfortable in who I am."

Swift and Kelce started dating after she performed her "Eras Tour" in Kansas City in July 2023. Kelce later said on his podcast that he tried and failed to give her a friendship bracelet with his phone number on it, leading the two to connect. And the rest was history.

In in the interview, Kelce also discussed playing his 13th season in the NFL. Andrews said there was a speculation among fans over whether or not the three-time Super Bowl champ would play another year. The 2024-2025 season notably ended in heartbreak for his team, with the Philadelphia Eagles defeating the Chiefs, 40-22, in the Super Bowl. (Kelce's interview with Andrews aired Sept. 14, the same day as the Chiefs-Eagles rematch game at Kansas City's Arrowhead Stadium.)

"I love what I do," Kelce said. "I'm still a kid on Sundays that enjoys every single aspect of the game. I built a family here. I don't want to give that up yet. I still feel like I've got a lot to prove."

title: When Does the Emmys Red Carpet Open? How To Watch Pre-Shows
summary: The 2025 Emmy Awards are almost here! Here's how to tune into pre-shows covering all the red carpet arrivals.
story: The 2025 Emmy Awards are almost here!
On Sunday, Sept. 14, the red carpet at the Peacock Theater in Los Angeles will be filled with Hollywood’s most stylish celebs attending the 77th annual Emmy Awards.
“The Penguin,” “The White Lotus,” “The Last of Us,” “Severance” and “The Studio” were among the titles that earned the most nominations this award season.

Quinta Brunson (“Abbott Elementary”), Ayo Edebiri (“The Bear”) and Jean Smart (“Hacks”) are among the nominees for best lead actress in a comedy series, while Seth Rogen (“The Studio”), Jason Segel (“Shrinking”), Martin Short (“Only Murders in the Building”) and more are nominated in the best lead actor in a comedy series.

For best lead actor in a drama series, Sterling K. Brown (“Paradise”), Adam Scott (“Severance”) and Noah Wyle (“The Pitt”) earned nominations, while Kathy Bates (“Matlock”), Sharon Horgan (“Bad Sisters”), Keri Russell (“The Diplomat”) and more are nominated for best lead actress in a drama series.
Before the Emmys are handed out, fans can tune into the pre-show red carpet specials to see what their favorite celebrities and nominees are wearing to the event.
Here’s what to know about the red carpet pre-shows for the 2025 Emmy Awards.
When Are the 2025 Emmy Awards?
The 77th annual Emmy Awards take place on Sunday, Sept. 14, at Los Angeles’ Peacock Theater.
The show, which kicks off at 8 p.m. ET, will be hosted by comedian Nate Bargatze and is expected to run until 11 p.m. ET.
Where to Watch 2025 Emmy Awards Red Carpet Pre-Shows
Fans who want to tune-in to watch the fanfare before the Emmy Awards can find plenty of pre-show content.
On CBS, “ET: Live on the Emmys Red Carpet” will air at 7 p.m. ET on Sunday, Sept. 14, hosted by "Entertainment Tonight’s" Kevin Frazier and Nischelle Turner.
"E!" will also have plenty of pre-show content for viewers.
“Live From E!: Countdown to the 2025 Emmys” airs at 5 p.m. ET and will feature Bresha Webb, Melissa Peterman and Zanna Roberts Rassi as they discuss the award show's nominees and arrivals.
Afterward, “Live From E!: 2025 Emmys” airs at 6 p.m. ET, which will feature Zuri Hall and Heather McMahan interviewing celebrities right from the red carpet.
Where to Watch 2025 Emmy Awards
The Emmy Awards will air live on CBS, with the event starting at 8 p.m. ET. Premium plan subscribers will also be able to stream the award show live on Paramount+.

title: Country Stars Gavin Adcock and Zach Bryan Appear to Have Heated Confrontation at Oklahoma Festival
summary: Zach Bryan and Gavin Adcock appeared to have had a heated confrontation at a musical festival in Oklahoma
story: Zach Bryan and Gavin Adcock appeared to have had a heated confrontation at a musical festival in Oklahoma.

The country music artist was set to perform at the Born & Raised Festival in Pryor, Oklahoma on Saturday, Sept. 13. However, before his set, Adcock got into a brief altercation with Bryan on the festival grounds.
Adcock shared a short clip of their interaction in a video on Instagram. In the clip, the two artists were separated by a fence as they argued with one another.
At one point, Bryan was heard yelling at Adcock, and appeared to say, “Hey, do you want to fight like a man? Come open the gate,” before aggressively pushing the chainlink fence.
“When you get death threats from Sack Cryin before you headline in his hometown,” Adock wrote on the video, captioning the post, “Eat a snickers bro.”

Other angles of the argument were shared across social media, including a clip that captured Bryan scaling the fence, which included a barbed wire trim across the top. People standing by told Bryan repeatedly to get down off the fence, which he did…after he climbed over to the other side.
Another clip shared on X caught the aftermath, which included Bryan charging toward Adcock before he was held back by onlookers. Adcock was seen pointing at Bryan before walking away.

Adcock's comment section on his Instagram post was divided on the altercation, with one Instagram user writing, “Bro he scaled a barbwire fence , called you out, and you didn’t do s--- and hid behind security…. We alll saw the full video… this lil clip ain’t fooling anyone….”
“had a show to play for Oklahoma,” Adcock wrote in response to the commenter. “Wasn’t. Going to jail over that Pshyco.”
TODAY.com has reached to representatives for Adcock and Bryan.

The tension between the musicians seemingly dates back to a feud from over the summer, when Adcock called out Bryan on social media for how he treated a teenaged fan, per Rolling Stone. In July, Adcock wrote on X, “If you can’t handle the criticism of a 14 year old why do people idolize you?”

“That kid was head over heels to meet you and spent/ parents spent a ton of money to see you,” he added. “He’s got feeling too and a you’re a ‘grown man” nearly 30. They’re the only reason you are around.”

During an August appearance on an episode of Rolling Stone’s “Nashville Now” podcast, Adcock reflected on the moment, explaining, “It wasn’t about not wanting to sign autographs after a show, it’s like letting a 14-year-old kid rant, without saying, ‘get off my d--k.’ You’re bigger than that.”

“I think that Zach Bryan puts on a big mask in his day-to-day life and sometimes he can’t help but rip it off and show his true colors,” he added. “I don’t know if Zach Bryan’s really that great of a person.”
Adcock clarified his relationship with Bryan, adding, “I ain’t his buddy, he ain’t my buddy. I ain’t met the guy. I don’t need him.”

title: Patrick Schwarzenegger Marries Abby Champion in Star-Studded Wedding. See the Guest List
summary: Patrick Schwarzenegger married his longtime girlfriend Abby Champion in a picturesque ceremony in Idaho
story: Patrick Schwarzenegger married his longtime girlfriend Abby Champion in a picturesque ceremony in Idaho.

The couple, who announced their engagement in December 2023, were married in Coeur d’Alene, Idaho on Sept. 6, per Vogue. The wedding was a star-studded event, spanning several days of wedding activities for the bride and groom and their guests.
The newlyweds were joined by their parents, Maria Shriver and Arnold Schwarzenegger, and Laura and Greg Champion.

Their siblings were also in attendance, including Champion’s brothers Luke and Joshua and her sister, Baskin. The “White Lotus” star’s brother, Christopher Schwarzenegger, and brother-in-law, Chris Pratt, were both groomsmen, with Christopher giving a speech at the wedding.
Other celebrity attendees included Rob Lowe’s son John Owen Lowe, who served as a groomsman and, per the magazine, helped initially set the couple up.

Schwarzenegger’s “White Lotus” co-stars also made the trip out to Idaho to celebrate the couple, including his on-screen father, Jason Isaacs, and siblings, Sarah Catherine Hook and Sam Nivola, who played Piper and Lochlan Ratliff, respectively. The group were photographed together during the pre-wedding festivities, including Nivola’s girlfriend, Iris Apatow.

Taylor Lautner was also in attendance, sharing a photo on his Instagram story posing with Schwarzenegger and Isaacs. This also served as a reunion for Lautner and Isaacs, who played on-screen father and son in 2011’s “Abduction.”
Schwarzenegger and Champion first met in 2015 while she was on a date with one of their mutual friends, per Vogue.

The Champion's date invited his friends to meet up with them at the bar afterward, which included Schwarzenegger, and he and Champion instantly clicked. She recalled, “He got my number, asked me out, and the rest is history.”
The couple went Instagram official in February 2016 and got engaged seven years later in December 2023.
Shriver celebrated the news on Instagram, sharing at the time that she was “beyond thrilled” by her son’s engagement.

“They love each other, they accept one another, they cheer one another on,” Shriver wrote. “They are each others best friend, confidante, and cheerleader. Their love is something to behold. I’m so happy for them, for their now, and for their future!”
While Pratt served as one of his brother-in-law’s groomsmen, as it turns out, he almost ruined the couple’s surprise proposal.
During a March appearance on “The Kelly Clarkson Show,” Schwarzenegger said that he wanted the proposal to be “unique.”

He explained that they went on a sunrise walk at the beach, which became the site of the proposal. Both of their families were on standby hiding at a lifeguard station on the beach, except for Pratt, who was tasked with aiding in the surprise.

“And Chris (Pratt), my brother-in-law, set up an umbrella on the beach, and he set up all these roses and all these flowers, and then right when we walked down, he jumped up with the umbrella and ran away, and there was this beautiful flower arrangement,” he explained. “That’s where I proposed.”

However, Pratt’s exit from the scene wasn’t so smooth, which tipped off Champion. Schwarzenegger said that she didn’t suspect anything until she saw Pratt run away “at the last second,” adding, “She’s like, ‘Is that Chris?’ And I was like, ‘Yeah.’”
Schwarzenegger revealed during a March appearance on “The Drew Barrymore Show” that if he had not booked “The White Lotus” gig, he and Champion would have already been married.

“We’ve been together forever. When we get married, it will be 10 years,” he explained. “Finally, a year and a half ago we got engaged. It was our moment, it was this great thing and about a few days later, I booked ‘White Lotus.’ And I was like, ‘Abby, I know we’re in this high of engagement and we’re going to get married this year, but we’re going to have to push it.’”
Schwarzenegger said that he told Champion that in booking the role, he would have to go to Thailand for seven months to film.
However, that didn’t put a damper on their excitement, with the actor adding, “She was so happy. She was ecstatic because she’s a huge fan.”

title: What Lorne Michaels Said to Bowen Yang After He Asked If He Should Stay on 'SNL'
summary: Bowen Yang revealed Lorne Michael's message to Him after SNL' cuts.
story: Bowen Yang is here to stay at “Saturday Night Live.”
Ahead of Season 51 of the late-night sketch comedy show, several cast members confirmed their departure, including the show’s mainstays Heidi Gardner and Ego Nwodim.
Yang opened up to People about why he’s decided to stick around for another season and the words of wisdom he received from the show’s creator, Lorne Michaels.
He told the outlet, “I’ve always gone by the instinct of, do I have more to do? And I feel like I do.”

“Even Lorne and I talked about it, and Lorne was like, ‘You have more to do,’ and that means a lot, because I even confessed to him,” Yang explained. “I was like, ‘I feel the audience is maybe getting sick of me.’ And he was like, ‘That’s not true. There’s more for you to do. I need you.’”

Yang said that he has “to honor that,” adding, “That man has changed my life, and I owe a lot of my life to that show. And I love working there, the people are the best. I really love each of them so much.”

The comedian became a writer on the show in 2018 before joining the cast the next year in 2019. During his time on “SNL,” he's become a versatile cast member, including several memorable moments at the “Weekend Update” desk as the iceberg that sunk the Titanic and Moo Deng.

As for how Yang feels going into a new season with several of his cast members not returning, he shared, “What I’ve always thought, what I think everybody knows, is that ‘SNL’ is this boot camp, and that implies that there is a next phase you train for something else.”

“It’s always a transitional place, and I think it is always a launching pad,” he added, using co-star Kenan Thompson as an example. “I think that’s going to be true for all of the people who aren’t coming back. I’m so excited to see what they do. I’m excited for the new cast.”
In an August interview with Puck News, Michaels teased an impending shakeup after the show’s landmark 50th season.
Subsequent weeks revealed the results, including the departure of new cast members Michael Longfellow, Devon Walker and Emil Wakim, and writers Ben Higgins and Celeste Yim.
Gardner, who joined the show in 2017, has not acknowledged her departure publicly yet.
Nwodim, who joined in 2018, announced her departure from the show on Sept. 12 after the cast had seemingly been solidified.

The comedian shared a statement on Instagram that she would be leaving “after seven unforgettable seasons,” writing in part, “Week after week on that stage taught me more than I could have ever imagined, and I will carry those memories (and that laughter) with me always.”
Chloe Fineman, who is entering her seventh season on the show, told Extra TV on Sept. 11 that the shakeups at “SNL” were “pretty wild.”
“Some shocking stuff,” she added. “A little heartbreak, sadness. I haven’t fully processed anything, but I will say the show has such a turnover.”
“SNL” returns on Saturday, Oct. 4, 2025, for the Season 51.

While the new season brought a series of departures, it also included several new cast members: Tommy Brennan, Jeremy Culhane, Kam Patterson and Veronika Slowikowska. Ben Marshall, who is part of the comedy group “Please Don’t Destroy” and joined the writing staff in 2021, is also being promoted to a cast member.

title: Could Taylor Swift Attend the Chiefs' Super Bowl Rematch Against the Eagles This Weekend?
summary: Could Taylor Swift be at the Chiefs game Sunday? The newly engaged star missed last week's Brazil opener. Latest on her 2025 NFL attendance plans.
story: As the Kansas City Chiefs head into Week 2 of their 2025 season, fans are keeping their eyes peeled to see if Taylor Swift shows up to watch her new fiancé, Travis Kelce, take the field with his teammates.

The Chiefs, who lost their first game of the season to the Los Angeles Chargers on Sept. 5 in Brazil, return home to Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City, Missouri, on Sept. 14 to face off against the Philadelphia Eagles.

Swift was an avowed Eagles fan before taking up with Kelce in 2023. Since then, the "Karma" singer has attended a number of Chiefs home games and two Super Bowls, including the 2025 Super Bowl when the Eagles beat the Chiefs, 40-22.
Swift was a no-show, however, at the Chiefs' Week 1 game last week. She also skipped the MTV Video Music Awards in New York two days later.
Could Swift show up to Arrowhead this weekend to cheer for her future groom? As any Swiftie knows, she's currently not on tour, though she is set to release a new album.
When Do the Chiefs Play the Eagles?
The Kansas City Chiefs take on the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday, Sept. 14, at Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City, Missouri.
What Time Do the Chiefs Play the Eagles?
The game is scheduled to kick off at 4:25 p.m. ET.
How to Watch the Chiefs-Eagles Game
The game will air live on Fox. Sports lovers can also stream the game on the Fox Sports website and app.
The game will also be available to stream on "NFL Sunday Ticket" on YouTube and YouTube TV for a fee. Free trial offers are available.

title: Sharon Osbourne Pens 1st Message Since Ozzy Osbourne’s Death: 'Still Finding My Footing'
summary: Sharon Osbourne is expressing her gratitude for the abundance of support she's received since the death of her husband, heavy metal legend Ozzy Osbourne.
story: Sharon Osbourne is expressing her gratitude for the abundance of support she's received since the death of her husband, heavy metal legend Ozzy Osbourne.
In her first Instagram post Sept. 12 since the Black Sabbath frontman’s death in July, Sharon Osbourne thanked her followers for “the overwhelming love and support” on social media.
“Your comments, posts, and tributes have brought me more comfort than you know. None of it has gone unnoticed, in fact, it’s carried me through many nights," she wrote.
Alongside her message, Sharon Osbourne shared a video of herself and daughter Kelly Osbourne in a field, with birds flying onto her gloved hand.

“Though I’m still finding my footing, I wanted to share some glorious creatures I had the chance to spend an afternoon with. The connection you make with these powerful birds is built entirely on trust and confidence,” she continued.
Explaining that the birds will only perch “if they sense you are safe and unafraid of them,” she added, “it’s a bond I know all too well.”
“I love you all, and I thank you deeply for the otherworldly amount of love you continue to send my way,” she concluded the post, adding a peace sign and a heart emoji.
Members of Ozzy Osbourne's family shared news of the rock singer's death in a statement July 22.
“He was with his family and surrounded by love. We ask everyone to respect our family privacy at this time,” the statement read.

The message was signed by Sharon Osbourne and their children, Jack Osbourne, Kelly Osbourne and Aimee Osbourne. Louis Osbourne, whom Ozzy Osbourne shared with ex-wife Thelma Riley, signed the statement, as well.

Ozzy Osbourne reportedly died at 76 from a heart attack, according a death certificate obtained by The New York Times. Cardiac arrest, coronary artery disease and Parkinson’s disease with autonomic dysfunction were also listed as causes of death.
While Sharon Osbourne's Sept. 12 Instagram post marks the first time the singer's wife posted on social media about his death, their daughter Kelly Osbourne shared a message days after his passing.
In an Instagram story July 24, Kelly Osbourne quoted Black Sabbath’s 1972 hit “Changes,” writing, “I feel unhappy. I am so sad. I lost the best friend I ever had,” with a broken heart emoji.

title: How Natalie Wood’s 13-Year-Old Granddaughter Takes After the Star, According to Her Mom
summary: Natalie Wood's 13-year-old granddaughter is already reminding her family of the classic Hollywood icon.
story: Natalie Wood's 13-year-old granddaughter is already reminding her family of the classic Hollywood icon.

In light of relaunching her fragrance brand inspired by the “Rebel Without a Cause” star, Natalie Wood’s daughter Natasha Gregson Wagner reflected on keeping her daughter, Clover, connected to her mom.
“Clover is a very sensitive person. And I think she has that example in her grandma, being vulnerable but also such force,” Gregson Wagner, 54, said in an interview with People.
As Clover enters her teenage years, Gregson Wagner said her daughter has a newfound curiosity for her grandmother.

“She’s curious about my mom’s level of fame,” Gregson Wagner told the publication. “She’s aware of young people that are famous and she’ll say, ‘How famous was she?’ Like Justin and Hailey Bieber or something?’”
Of Wood's films, Gregson Wagner said Clover has seen the 1961 romantic drama “Splendor in the Grass.”
"That’s a pretty intense film, so she’s intrigued by the emotional spectrum of her performances,” Gregson Wagner said.
In 2016, Gregson Wagner launched the fragrance line Natalie, which she told People was inspired by Wood’s gardenia scent. She's now relaunching the brand under the name L’Amour Mēre.
L’Amour Mēre has three scents: Natalie, in honor of Wood; C-Love, inspired by Clover; and Lyublyu, which means "love" in Russian and is inspired by Gregson Wagner's grandmother.
Clover is one of the faces of their new campaign, according to the outlet and photos shared on social media.
“I think it’s just my way of connecting my daughter to my mom,” Gregson Wagner told the publication of the campaign.
Gregson Wagner, who shares Clover with her husband, actor Barry Watson, was 11 years old when Wood died of drowning in November 1981. Wood was 43.

The California native, born to Russian immigrant parents, starred in her first blockbuster film, “Miracle on 34th Street,” at just 8 years old in 1947. By the time she was a teenager, Wood was nominated for an Oscar for her performance in “Rebel Without a Cause” and “The Searchers.” She was later nominated for “Splendor in the Grass” and “Love with the Proper Stranger.”
Wood was also known for her musical performances, starring in “West Side Story” and “Gypsy” in the 1960s.

Wood was first married to actor Robert Wagner until the couple divorced in 1962. In 1969, she married her second husband, film producer Richard Gregson, with whom she welcomed Gregson Wagner. The two divorced in 1972. In 1974, Wood remarried Robert Wagner and gave birth to daughter Courtney Wagner.
In a 2016 interview with People, Gregson Wagner opened up about the men who raised her after her mother's death, adding that she still calls Robert Wagner, “Daddy Wagner.”

In May, Robert Wagner celebrated Clover's 13th birthday, writing on Instagram, "Grandma and I are so proud of you and the young woman you’re becoming. Welcome to your teenage years—this is just the beginning of a wonderful journey. We love you so much."

title: Mötley Crüe Singer Vince Neil Reveals He Had Stroke That Temporarily Paralyzed His ‘Whole Left Side’
summary: Vince Neil is opening up about his recent health scare, which led to Mötley Crüe postponing their Las Vegas residency
story: Vince Neil is opening up about his recent health scare, which led to Mötley Crüe postponing their Las Vegas residency.
During a Sept. 12 interview with the Las Vegas Review-Journal, Neil revealed that he had a stroke at the end of 2024.
The musician said he felt fine when he went to sleep on Christmas night, but when he woke up, he wasn’t able to get out of bed. He explained, “My whole left side went out.”
Neil reflected on his recovery journey post-stroke, telling the publication, “I had to learn to walk again, and that was tough.”
“The doctors said they didn’t think I’d be able to go back on stage again,” he said. “I go, ‘No, no, I’m gonna do it. Watch and see.’”
The musician’s recovery process required the band’s shows in Las Vegas to be postponed by several months.

On March 4, Mötley Crüe announced on social media that their Las Vegas residency, set to run between March 28 to April 19, would be moved to September “due to a required medical procedure” advised by Neil’s doctors.
Neil told the Las Vegas Review-Journal that the band's decision to reschedule the dates was so he “could get better.”

The musician spent months in physical therapy at his home in Nashville, Tennessee. Opening up about his progress, he said, “I went from people carrying me to the bathroom, because I couldn’t walk myself, finally to a wheelchair.”
“I graduated to a walker, and then I had a cane,” he added. “Now I don’t need anything. But it’s like a full-time job getting back to where you feel good again.”
While the singer clarified his voice wasn’t affected by the stroke, he detailed his difficult journey learning to move his body the same way as before.
“It takes a while to get your brain to start moving your legs, for them to do what your brain wants to do,” he explained. “You try to walk but it doesn’t come out right.”
Through his recovery period, not only has Neil re-learned to walk, he taught himself how to run again, adding that he’s “90-95% to where I was before.”
His months-long recovery led up to the band's residency, which kicked off Sept. 12. Mötley Crüe is scheduled perform a limited run of 10 shows until Oct. 3 at Dolby Live at Park MGM.
After the original residency dates were postponed, Neil shared a message with fans, which read in part, “To all the Crüeheads who were looking forward to see us this Spring, I’m truly sorry.”

“My health is my top priority so I can bring you the awesome shows you deserve, and I can’t wait to return to the stage,” he added. “Thank you for all the well wishes that keep reaching me. Your support means more than you know.”
His bandmates Nikki Sixx, Tommy Lee and John 5 also shared a message of support at the time, wishing their bandmate “a speedy recovery.”

“We are looking forward for him to get well again and to take over Vegas together in September,” they said. “We can’t wait to see you all out there, and thank you for your understanding and support in the meantime.”

title: Malcolm-Jamal Warner’s Wife Addresses His Death in Emotional Tribute Marking Wedding Anniversary
summary: Malcolm-Jamal Warner's wife, Tenisha Warner, is sharing publicly for the first time since her husband's drowning death in July.
story: Malcolm-Jamal Warner's wife, Tenisha Warner, is sharing publicly for the first time since her husband's drowning death in July.

In honor of their wedding anniversary, Tenisha Warner shared a tribute Sept. 12 on Instagram for the “Cosby Show” star, alongside a photo of the couple laughing on what appeared to be their wedding day.
“Tomorrow marks our anniversary —and my heart is wide open,” she wrote. “For the first time,I’m sharing a glimpse of the love that began it all.”

“I can still hear my husband’s laugh, still feel the way he made room for every part of me —every tear, every dream,” she continued. “Today, in his honor, my daughter and I are launching River & Ember and officially opening The Warner Family Foundation.”

Her touching words were shared in a joint post that included her husband Malcolm-Jamal Warner's Instagram account, along with the accounts of River & Ember and The Warner Family Foundation, which Tenisha Warner wrote "carry the legacy my husband and I began—one that nurtures children’s inner light and gives young artists the freedom to create outside the lines.”
“This is love, Still moving. Still making,” she concluded the post.

After the photo, Tenisha Warner shared a statement, introducing their new company, River & Ember. She said the company’s name was inspired by Malcolm-Jamal Warner, writing that “his presence was a river — steady, sure and always moving toward what matters” and that “his spirit was an ember — glowing with encouragement, igniting possibility in those around him.”

“My husband believed deeply in tending not only to the inner light in children, but in ourselves,” she wrote. “This company carries forward that belief — offering stories and rituals that honor the quiet power of connection between parent and child.”

She continued, “This work is the continuation of that presence he embodied. Through story and ritual, I hope to offer families the same gifts he gave us: a sense of being held, and a reminder that even in life’s changing seasons, our inner light is worth tending.”

Malcolm-Jamal Warner died July 20 at 54 in an an accidental drowning while on vacation in Costa Rica with his wife and daughter. According to Costa Rica’s Judicial Investigation Agency (OIJ), he died as a result of asphyxia by submersion.

The OIJ said at the time that a male victim entered the water and “apparently was dragged by a current offshore.” People at the scene rescued Warner and brought him back to shore, per the release, but he could not be revived.
In an August 8 tribute on Instagram, the actor's mother, Pamela Warner, wrote that her son “did not suffer.”

“Malcolm was birthed through water and transitioned through water. This was his time. His mission on earth had been completed,” she shared. “Hold close to whatever part of Malcolm’s life that touched yours. In keeping it near, you keep his spirit alive — nourishing you with the peace, love, joy and light that embodied Malcolm-Jamal Warner.”

Pamela Warner remembered her son as a father who was "immensely proud of and loved fiercely." She also recalled his "love" of performing, writing that he had been entertaining those around him since the age of 8.

Malcolm-Jamal Warner is best known for his role as Theo Huxtable on “The Cosby Show” from 1984-1992, which garnered him an Emmy Award nomination in 1986. He then starred in popular sitcoms “Malcolm & Eddie” and “Reed Between the Lines,” later appearing in shows like “The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air,” “9-1-1” and “Sons of Anarchy.”

The actor's repertoire included films like “Fool’s Gold” with Matthew McConaughey and Kate Hudson, as well as “Restaurant” with Adrien Brody. Malcolm-Jamal Warner didn't shy away from stage performance, appearing in productions like “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” and “Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner.”
In 2015, Malcolm-Jamal Warner won a Grammy Award for best traditional R&B performance for “Jesus Children.”

title: Canelo Álvarez vs. Terence Crawford: Everything to Know About the Fight
summary: Canelo Álvarez and Terence Crawford will be facing off against one another in one of the most anticipated fights of the year in Las Vegas. Here's what to know.
story: The moment you've been waiting for is almost here!
Canelo Álvarez and Terence Crawford, two of the biggest stars in boxing, are set to fight one another in one of the most anticipated matches of the year.
The duo, who will go head-to-head at the Allegiant Stadium in Las Vegas on Saturday, Sept. 13, are both gearing up to take home a championship belt and prize money.
"For me, it is a very important fight to win," Álvarez told Ring Magazine in an interview.
The undisputed super middleweight champion explained that he plans on using "motivation" and "discipline" to win the fight.
"That two combined is very good," he said.

As for Crawford, who has been described as the underdog, he said he believes he also has a good chance of winning. The undefeated former undisputed welterweight champion moved up from 154 pounds to 168 pounds to challenge Álvarez.
In an interview with Ring magazine, he said he believes his heavier weight will not slow him down.
"Listen, a lot of people say I'm slow, a lot of people say adding weight, fat, muscle, will make you slower so I just told everyone, let's see how slow I am come fight night," he said.

“When you look at the history of boxing, more little men have moved up in weight to beat the bigger man in boxing," he added. "...I can name fighters for days that was smaller, that moved up in weight consistently and was successful."
Scroll below to see how you can watch the Canelo vs. Crawford fight.
What time does the Canelo vs. Crawford Fight Start?
The Canelo Álvarez vs. Terence Crawford fight card, or program lineup, consists of 10 matches.
The event will see Álvarez and Crawford go up against each other, as well as Christian Mbilli vs. Lester Martinez, Callum Walsh vs. Fernando Vargas Jr. and more.
The preliminary card is set to begin at 5:30 p.m. ET/2:30 p.m. PT and the main card, featuring the Canelo vs. Crawford fight, will start at 9 p.m. ET/6 p.m. PT.
How to Watch Canelo vs. Crawford Fight
The Canelo vs. Crawford fight will stream live from the Allegiant Stadium in Las Vegas on Netflix.
To watch the fight, you must have a Netflix subscription which costs $7.99 a month with ads and around $17.99 to $24.99 a month without ads, depending on which plan you get.
The premium plan allows you to watch Netflix in 4K while the standard plan offers 1080p.
Will the Canelo vs. Crawford Fight Stream Live?
The preliminary card will be streamed live on Tudum at 5:30 p.m. ET/2:30 p.m. PT, while the main card matches will be streamed live globally on Netflix at 9 p.m. ET/6 p.m. PT.
